questions.text: One of the mechanisms for intestinal sugar absorption is mediated by the Na+-K+ ATPase pump. Which of the following sugars require sodium for absorption? Glucose Sucrose Galactose Fructose Maltose Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, & 3 are correct Statements: 1 and 3. Glucose and Galactose Galactose and Glucose are transported into mucosal cells by an active , energy-requiring process that requires a concurrent uptake of sodium ions and this transport protein is SGLT-1 (Sodium-dependent Glucose Tramantransport). Sodium-dependent transporter of glucose SGLT-1 → Small intestine and Kidneys → for Glucose and Galactose SGLT-2 → Kidneys → only for Glucose

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Statement: 4. Fructose Fructose uptake requires a sodium-independent monosaccharide transporter GLUT-5 for its absorption. It is present in the small intestine, and testis (seminal fluid) as the major energy source of sperm is fructose. Statement: 2 and 5: Sucrose and maltose The sucrose and maltose upon digestion by intestinal enzymes also give rise to glucose. However, if we read the question carefully, the question is asking about absorption only but not digestion and then absorption of these sugars. The conversion of disaccharides to monosaccharides is considered under digestion. so, it is more apt to choose all four (A, B, C, and E) only if there is digestion and absorption mentioned in the question.

questions.text: GLUTs and SGLTs are two types of sugar transporter present in the intestine and kidneys. Which of the following transporters is defective in renal glycosuria?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SGLT- 2 In this disease , blood glucose is normal, b ut still Glucose appears in the urine . It is due to a defect/mutation in SGLT - 2 , which is major glucose transporter (90% glucose reabsorption) present in kidneys for the reabsorption and transport of Glucose (see fig below).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. GLUT-1 GLUT-1 is an insulin-independent transporter for the basal uptake of glucose in the brain, placenta, and RBCs. Option: B. GLUT-2 GLUT-2 is present in hepatocytes and pancreatic beta cells and intestine In the intestine: help in basolateral transport of glucose in the In hepatocytes: Glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis in the fed state. In pancreatic cells : release of insulin by acting as glucose and energy sensor. GLUT-2 expression is also increased in the presence of insulin. Option: C. SGLT-1 SGLT-1 is major transporter in the intestine for the absorption of glucose and galactose and is also responsible for 10% glucose reabsorption in the kidneys. So, the mutation in SGLT-1 leads to glucose-galactose malabsorption

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding sugar transport in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: GLUT-2 responsible for glucose and fructose absorption

options.label: B
options.text: Glucose is absorbed independent of Sodium

questions.correct_answer: D. SGLT-2 is specific for glucose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SGLT-2 is specific for glucose SGLT-2 is major glucose transporter (90% glucose reabsorption) present in kidneys (in renal tubules. Deficiency of SGLT-2 leads to renal glycosuria with glucose excretion in urine.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. GLUT-2 responsible for glucose and fructose absorption GLUT-2 is only for glucose transport: In the intestine: help in basolateral transport of glucose in the kidneys. In hepatocytes: Glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis in the fed state. In pancreatic cells : release of insulin by acting as glucose and energy sensor. Option: B. Glucose is absorbed independent of Sodium Glucose is absorbed from the intestine by Sodium dependent secondary active transport. The transporter SGLT-1 is a co-transporter of Na and Glucose Sodium is also required for the Na + -K + ATPase pump later in the process. Option: C. Fructose requires sodium for absorption Fructose is absorbed using GLUT - 5 , which does not require sodium. GLUT-5 is abundant in the small intestine and testis (seminal fluid).

questions.text: One manner in which type 2 diabetes occurs is via a reduction in the release of insulin from the pancreas. The release of insulin from the β-cells of the pancreas requires which of the following GLUT transporters?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GLUT-2 Option: B. GLUT-2 Is present in the pancreas, intestine, and liver It is active in the fed state. It acts as a glucose sensor in blood and allows glucose uptake in the pancreas postprandially for stimulation and release of insulin from beta cells of the pancreas (see fig below).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. GLUT-4 Once insulin is released in the blood, it will make GLUT-4 active. GLUT-4 is present in peripheral tissues (skeletal muscles, cardiac muscles, adipose tissues) through which glucose enters the peripheral tissues, and this way blood glucose is ↓ leading to the hypoglycemic action of insulin. Option: C and D. GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 are involved in basal glucose uptake. GLUT-1 is present in Brain, Placenta, Kidney, RBC GLUT-3 is present in Brain (Neuronal), Placenta, Kidneys

questions.text: A variety of passive glucose transporters (GLUTs) are involved in glucose transport to various tissues and organs under different conditions. After overnight fasting, GLUTs are reduced in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adipose tissues Synthesis of GLUT-4 channels is induced in response to insulin secretion after a carbohydrate-rich. They transport glucose to Skeletal muscles Cardiac muscles Adipose tissues Once the blood glucose is transported, their number also gets So, after an overnight fast (low blood glucose), these GLUTs will be reduced in skeletal muscles, cardiac muscles & adipose tissues due to low insulin.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options: A, B, and C: Brain, RBC, and Kidney Brain, RBCs, and Kidneys are vital for survival and require glucose in fasting. They absorb glucose via insulin-independent GLUT channels GLUT-1 and 3 So, expression of these GLUTs will be increased in fasting in these organs.

questions.text: A child of 5 years of age was given high fructose corn syrup. The child develops abdominal pain and diarrhea. Consultation with the physician and the history of the patient reveals the occurrence of dietary fructose intolerance in the child. Deficiency of one of the following is implicated in the pathophysiology of the disorder?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GLUT-5 GLUT-5 is the exclusive fructose transporter. It is expressed in the apical borders of enterocytes in the small intestine. It brings about the facilitated transport of fructose from the lumen of the small intestine to inside the enterocytes in favor of the fructose concentration gradient.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: B. GLUT-1 expresses in all body tissues, predominantly in the erythrocytes and tissues in the blood-brain barrier . Option: D. GLUT 3 is mainly expressed in neurons and transport glucose in the neurons

questions.text: Arrange the following in sequence occurring in a fed state: Insulin GLUT-2 Uptake of glucose by skeletal muscles GLUT-4 Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2→1→4→3 Option: C. 2→1→4→3 During Fed state: GLUT-2 ⇒ Insulin ⇒ GLUT- 4 ⇒ Uptake of glucose by skeletal muscles After the reduction of blood glucose, GLUT-2 expression is decreased causing low insulin and low GLUT-4 expression.

questions.text: Which of the following DOES NOT depend on insulin for glucose uptake?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Brain In the brain , glucose uptake is mediated by GLUT-1 & GLUT-3 which are involved in basal glucose uptake in the fed and fasting state (mainly). These GLUTs are active irrespective of the presence or absence of insulin. So, there is no relation between insulin and these GLUTs or we can say that GLUT-1 and 3 are not dependent on insulin. So, Brain does not depend on insulin for glucose uptake. .

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options: B, C, and D. Cardiac muscles, Skeletal muscles, and Adipose tissue Glucose uptake occurs in muscles (cardiac & skeletal) & adipose tissue occurs via GLUT-4 , which is insulin-dependent (discussed in other questions).

questions.text: The facilitative transporter GLUT-2 is responsible for the activation of the insulin-induced GLUT-4 transporter and the transport of blood glucose to peripheral tissues. Mutation in GLUT-2 causes which of the following disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fanconi-Bickel syndrome The autosomal recessive condition caused due to allelic variants of GLUT-2 arose due to mutations . C/F Resembles type I GSD (von Gierke’s disease) - Glycogen deposited in the liver and kidney Fasting hypoglycemia but postprandial hyperglycemia Patients are usually dwarf, with rickets, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, glucosuria, Proximal tubulopathy, and hypercalciuria

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Menke’s disease It is a condition of Cu deficiency due to mutation in intestinal Cu transporter ATP7A Cu stays in intestinal cells, unable to enter blood causing ↓ plasma Cu C/F Kinky hair Greying of hair Growth Retardation Option: C. Beckwith syndrome Overgrowth syndrome is where the patient has macroglossia, macrosomia, organomegaly, and some developmental abnormalities especially abdominal wall defects like exomphalos. Option: D. Dandy-Walker syndrome It is a rare disorder affecting the brain where the cerebellum and fourth ventricle is mainly affected. It is usually caused by chromosomal genetic conditions causing impaired cell migration and division affecting the development of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text: The method of transport of glucose in the intestine is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary active transport The method of transport of glucose in the intestine is called Secondary active transport . Both glucose and Na + enter inside the cell (in the same direction) i.e. Symport. No energy is used when glucose and Na + enter the cell. Energy is used indirectly for glucose transport via Na + - K + ATPase pump. A sodium-glucose symporter carries 2Na + for each glucose In the intestine on the luminal surface, there is SGLT-1 (secondary active transport) while on the basal surface is GLUT-2 (facilitative transport)

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Primary active transport When the energy is directly used for the transport of a molecule across the membrane it is known as primary active transport. A lot of mineral ions such as Na + , K + , Mg 2+ , and Ca 2+ are transported by this method using an ion channel. Usually, the enzyme involved is an ATPase such as Na + - K + ATPase. Option: C. Simple Diffusion It is a type of passive transport where no energy is required as molecules move from a region of high concentration to a region of low concentration e.g. movement of gases O 2 and CO 2 during respiration The rate of diffusion depends on the permeability of the membrane. Option: D. Counter transport Also known as antiport 2 molecules are moved at the same time but in opposite directionsg. e.g. Na + - H + antiport and Na + - Ca + antiport. One molecule moves along the concentration gradient in one direction and the other moves in opposite direction with the help of carrier protein.

questions.text: True Statement regarding the intestinal brush border membrane is:

options.label: A
options.text: Amylase is only found in the brush border

options.label: B
options.text: Disaccharides can cross the brush border

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin is required for the uptake of glucose

options.label: D
options.text: Fructose requires a sodium-independent monosaccharide transporter

questions.correct_answer: D. Fructose requires a sodium-independent monosaccharide transporter
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fructose requires a sodium-independent monosaccharide transporter Fructose absorption is dependent on GLUT-5 which is a sodium-independent transporter This transporter is mainly present in the liver and testis.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Amylase is only found in the brush border Amylase is also found in saliva and pancreatic juice It is α-amylase which acts on α(1-4) glycosidic bonds of starch or glycogen and breaks it down into smaller maltose, maltotriose, and limit dextrins. The optimum pH of salivary amylase is 6.9 and that of pancreatic amylase is around 7. Option: B. Disaccharides can cross the brush border Disaccharides need to be broken down into their monosaccharides components by hydrolases before absorption. This action occurs by disaccharidases such as maltase, sucrase, and lactase, etc. present in brush border epithelium and so aka brush border enzyme Option: C. Insulin is required for the uptake of glucose GLUT-2 and GLUT-5 are present in the brush borer epithelium of the intestine. GLUT-2 is present in the basolateral membrane where as GLUT-5 is present at the anterior surface. Both are independent of insulin for their action
